newsitem.title: USA: Black deckhands, U.S. Army Engineer Corps settle.
newsitem.headline: Black deckhands, U.S. Army Engineer Corps settle.

text.p: A dozen black deckhands who brought a bias suit against the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers have accepted a settlement including $1.2 million in compensation and promotions, the government said Friday.
The settlement also covered four retired black workers from the Hurley, a Memphis-based dredging boat, and its predecessor, the Burgess. Two of the workers have since died.
Two white supervisors on the Hurley will be transferred to other posts, one a training and advising programme for the promoted deckhands, Army Corps spokesman Jim Pogue said.

"I needed to clean the atmosphere on the dredge," Col. Gregory Bean, head of the Army Corps' Memphis District, told Reuters. He said he wanted to remove any possibility that disciplinary actions would be perceived as retaliation for the settlement.
"My goal, and the goal of this settlement, is to clearly foster a workplace that values, appreciates and believes in the dignity of every individual," he said in a statement.
Managers in the district will get leadership training, and all employees will receive cultural diversity training.

The Pentagon, which oversees the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, its engineering and construction arm, issued a report earlier this year that criticised racial attitudes on the dredging boats, Bean said.
In interviews with The New York Times, one of the black deckhands characterised conditions on the Hurley as "modern-day slavery," and another said he was viewed as a "houseboy."

The black deckhands worked only during the dredging season, from mid-June to early November, when the Hurley covered hundreds of miles of the Mississippi River, clearing the channel bottom. Only white deckhands had full-time jobs maintaining the boat during the off-season, and they earned more.
